qas.question: What does Bellah say the separation of church and state is grounded firmly in?
What does Bellah use the term "civil religion' to describe?

answers.text: the specific relation between politics and religion

qas.question: Whose speech does Bellah's 1967 article analyze?
What word does Bellah ask how a President is justified to use?
What has the separation of church and state failed to deny the political realm of?
What does Bellah say the separation of church and state is not grounded firmly in?

plausible_answers.text: specific relation between politics and religion in the United States

qas.question: What doesn't Bellah use the term "civil religion' to describe?
Whose speech does Bellah's 1977 article analyze?
What word does Bellah ask how a President is justified to not use?
What has the separation of church and state failed to approve the political realm of?

context: Robert N. Bellah has in his writings that although the separation of church and state is grounded firmly in the <a0_0><b5_0>constitution of the United States<b5_0/><a0_0/>, this does not mean that there is no religious dimension in the political society of the United States. He used the term "Civil Religion" to describe <a1_0>the <b6_0>specific relation between politics and religion<a1_0/> in the United States<b6_0/>. His 1967 article analyzes the inaugural speech of <a2_0><b7_0>John F. Kennedy<b7_0/><a2_0/>: "Considering the separation of church and state, how is a president justified in using the word '<a3_0><b8_0>God<b8_0/><a3_0/>' at all? The answer is that the separation of church and state has not denied the political realm <a4_0>a <b9_0>religious dimension<b9_0/><a4_0/>."
